content.body: Where is the discussion for [Stop Coercing Things](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1m5R5J98W6adegghgkAlbSuFgAYJDT52yyFVdAqLjm00/edit)? I'm pretty sure most web platform APIs do coerce undefined.
content.formatted_body: Where is the discussion for Stop Coercing Things? I'm pretty sure most web platform APIs do coerce undefined.

content.body: Though perhaps this is mainly about required vs optional arguments in which case I could see where the comparison comes in, but that's a lot narrower.
Also, this should come with some kind of Web IDL story I think.
annevk: No discussion for it yet, since it hasn't been presented
content.formatted_body: annevk: No discussion for it yet, since it hasn't been presented

content.body: and yes it's intended to be about required vs optional, though also I thought web platform guidance was that `undefined` should be treated exactly like not passing an argument?

content.body: certainly that's how almost all ES functions work

or to put it a different way: ES already has the principle that passing an explicit `undefined` should be treated like leaving out an argument, in general, and if we additionally adopt the web-platform behavior of throwing when missing a required argument, that gets us all the way to "stop coercing undefined"
content.formatted_body: or to put it a different way: ES already has the principle that passing an explicit undefined should be treated like leaving out an argument, in general, and if we additionally adopt the web-platform behavior of throwing when missing a required argument, that gets us all the way to "stop coercing undefined"

content.body: updated the slides to make the claim about the web platform more correct
bakkot: undefined will be coerced when the argument is required, which is also the case for setters for instances
content.formatted_body: bakkot: undefined will be coerced when the argument is required, which is also the case for setters for instances

content.body: bakkot: so what you're asserting above is not how required arguments behave when undefined is passed to them
